stem: While reading a blog, a large banner suddenly shouts “Shockwave player out-of-date! Install now to keep reading.”

choices.A: Click and install so the page works
choices.B: Search the real player website later instead
choices.C: Refresh the blog until banner disappears
choices.D: Turn screen brightness down to ignore it

stem: Your cousin texts you a link “vidz-cool.store/LOLcat” saying it’s the funniest cat video ever.

choices.B: Open link and watch the video
choices.A: Ask cousin if they really sent it before opening
choices.C: Share link on your story so friends can laugh too
choices.D: Open link but mute the sound first

stem: At the airport, the free Wi-Fi splash page demands your full card number for age verification.

choices.A: Enter card and can cancel later
choices.C: Switch to your phone’s data instead
choices.B: Enter wrong card details to trick it
choices.D: Ignore card step and hope Wi-Fi still works

stem: While using the town library computer, a side window offers a speed booster plug-in claiming it will make all pages load twice as fast on public networks.

choices.B: Install quickly as loading is slow
choices.A: Check with library staff before installing anything
choices.C: Install, then delete it when done
choices.D: Install only if other patrons already have

stem: Your friend suggests downloading a movie from an unfamiliar site that asks you to turn off your browser’s safe download warning to continue.

choices.A: Disable the warning and grab the movie
choices.D: Look for the movie on a well-known streaming site instead
choices.C: Download but run it inside an isolated folder for better security
choices.B: Ask the site support chat if it’s safe

stem: A coffee shop Wi-Fi login page asks for your email and also wants permission to read your contact list to help you connect with friends here.

choices.B: Log in with just a nickname and skip contacts
choices.C: Use a friend’s email to log in
choices.D: Add contacts, then delete them later

stem: Your tablet shows two Wi-Fi options: “Mall_Free” and “Mall-Guest.” Both have identical signal and ask the same welcome questions, but only one appears on the mall’s posters.

choices.B: Pick the stronger signal so it has higher speeds
choices.A: Choose the name printed on posters even if signal is weaker
choices.C: Connect to both and test which is faster

stem: A software update alert pops up while you stream a movie on an unfamiliar site. It says “Required to continue playback” and offers a download that is only 200 KB.

choices.B: Close movie, then check for updates through the device’s own settings
choices.D: Download but save file to desktop first

stem: A colleague emails you a shortened link (t.ly/3AB) to meeting notes.

choices.A: Open link as it’s from work
choices.B: Preview the short link with an online expander before opening
choices.C: Forward link to teammates right away
choices.D: Open link only on your phone instead as it's more secure

stem: At a festival, a stall advertises instant phone charging if you install their companion app before plugging into their power bank station.

choices.A: Install to get a quick charge
choices.D: Use your own power bank or wait until later
choices.B: Plug in but keep phone screen locked

stem: A browser message says, “Allow site-wide notifications to receive exclusive coupon codes.” Declining blocks access to the shopping page’s checkout button.

choices.A: Allow notifications as coupons save money
choices.C: Open the site in a private window that blocks notifications
choices.B: Allow, then turn off later in settings
choices.D: Ask customer service for manual checkout link

stem: A conference hall projects a giant QR code labeled “Free event photos.” Scanning opens a page asking you to sign in with any social-media account to unlock high-resolution files.

choices.A: Sign in with your least-used social account
choices.B: Request the photos from the organizer’s official email instead
choices.C: Ask someone else to sign in first
choices.D: Use your main account but reset password later so you don't get hacked

stem: An online gaming forum offers a free lag-reducer tool. Downloading requires turning off the system’s antivirus because they give false alarms.

choices.A: Turn antivirus off as everyone on the forum recommends it
choices.B: Search reviews on independent sites before downloading anything
choices.D: Use a friend’s computer to test first

stem: You’re stuck at a train station with only public Wi-Fi available, but you must email a family photo that shows private medical information on a notice board behind you in the photo. In 1–3 sentences, explain the safest way you would send the photo or handle the situation.

rubric.point: Think twice: delay or use phone data/private hotspot if possible
If sending, crop or blur sensitive details first
Avoid uploading through sites you don’t fully trust on public Wi-Fi
